name: (2E)-1-phenylpropan-2-one semicarbazone
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1035

name: (2E)-1-phenylpropan-2-one semicarbazone
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1035
Reason: To predict the melting point for (2E)-1-phenylpropan-2-one semicarbazone, consider the following functional groups: ketone, phenyl group, and semicarbazone unit. Basic unit, acetophenone has a melting point of about 20°C. The semicarbazone group typically raises the melting point significantly because it forms strong hydrogen bonds and has high rigidity, contributing as much as +150°C. The additional alkene moiety in the (2E)-position has a minimal effect on the melting point due to limited changes in polarity and steric hindrance, perhaps leading to an additional +1 to +5°C increase.

name: (2E)-1-phenylpropan-2-one semicarbazone
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1035
Reason: To predict the melting point for (2E)-1-phenylpropan-2-one semicarbazone, consider the following functional groups: ketone, phenyl group, and semicarbazone unit. Starting with the basic unit, acetophenone, which has a melting point of about 20°C, the addition of each functional group will affect the melting point. Ketones generally increase the melting point due to their polar nature and the additional alkene moiety in the (2E)-position may contribute slightly due to increased molecular rigidity, leading to a slight increase in the melting point, estimated at +1 to +5°C. However, the key functional group influencing the melting point is the semicarbazone unit, which through its ability to form strong hydrogen bonds and its rigid structure, can increase the melting point significantly. Semicarbazones are known to elevate the melting points of the compounds they are a part of, sometimes resulting in an increase of around +150 to +170°C compared to the parent ketone. When summing these contributions, the predicted melting point will be higher than that of acetophenone, taking into account the observed impact of individual functional groups on melting points in similar compounds.
